flatirons.quote: Now we're going to learn how we can use the code window to make it easier to write, test, and experiment with code. Go ahead and open replit (https://replit.com/languages/javascript)
flatirons.comment: Replit.com has a new mode called "Spooky" that is pretty much unreadable that is used by default if you do not have an account. Go to https://replit.com/languages/javascript on a clean browser (i.e. no account), and spooky will be used by default. Notice that instead of "1 console.log('Hello, world!')", it looks like "1 .log[]'Hello, World'[]" . This is easy to replicate by creating a replit account, selecting Dark or Light as your theme, typing the aforementioned, then changing the theme to "spooky" and it becomes unreadable. You should interact with replit to get them to change the default no-account display, or update your course materials, or consider an alternative like codepen.

flatirons.quote: if (name === "Alice") { ... }
flatirons.comment: Why no semicolons after {} code blocks?  I'm still not convinced that if statements with curly braces and function declarations (which are still statements, if I am correct) should not have semicolons.

flatirons.quote: switch (name) {    case "Sleepy":    case "Sneezy":    case "Happy":    case "Grumpy":    case "Bashful":    case "Dopey":    case "Doc":    characterType = "dwarf";    break;
flatirons.comment: Switch is never the cleanest or shortest solution in any of these.  All you save with a switch is removing the "variable ===" but you have to add a "break" and an extra line if you are using else ifs.  If you're not using else ifs, then you could probably concatentate, instead of a new line for each dwarf you could do a number of OR expressions in a single line of an if.

flatirons.quote: Another way of thinking about Arrays is that they are like tables that have an identifier that is a Number. If we let the identifier be a String instead of an Number, then we'd basically be describing an Object.
flatirons.comment: if identifier = number    then thing = array if identifier = string    then thing = object if number != string    then array != object  But aren't arrays a type of object?  I mean literally, the typeof object?

flatirons.quote: (which isn't surprising, given that Arrays are a special type of Object)
flatirons.comment: See last comment

flatirons.quote: We can also provide one or two arguments to .slice(): the first is the index where the slice should begin and the second is the index before which it should end:
flatirons.comment: Would this be true if an index was missing?  Or is somethng like this not an array any more? {0:10, 10:11, 100:12}  It uses numbers, just not sequential.  (Note, nothing in previous lecture said arrays needed to be sequential--but it seems they do need to be.)

flatirons.quote: Method: Spread operator (...), What it does: Add element(s) to beginning or end of array
flatirons.comment: Change to: Method: Spread operator (...), What it does: expands element(s) of array, usually to add to beginning, middle, or end of array (italicize operator)

flatirons.quote: Method: .slice(), What it does: Remove 0 or more elements, Return value: A new array containing the removed elements
flatirons.comment: Change to: Method: .slice(), What it does: Retrieve 0 or more elements, Return value: A new array containing the replaced element(s)

flatirons.quote: Let's use the spread operator to copy all of the old menu Object's properties into a new Object: ... This will create a clone of the original object and save it into a new variable.
flatirons.comment: But that's not entirely true.  In previous lesson we learned that spread is shallow not deep.  Because we've created a pointer to CheesePlate, not a copy of CheesePlate.  function UpdateObject(obj, key, value) {   const newObj = {...obj};   newObj[key] = value; //Why are we using bracket notation here?    return newObj; }  const mondayMenu = {   cheesePlate: {     soft: "Chèvre",     semiSoft: "Gruyère",     hard: "Manchego",   },   fries: "Sweet potato",   salad: "Cobb", };  const tuesdayMenu = UpdateObject(mondayMenu, "salad", "Caesar");  tuesdayMenu.cheesePlate.soft = "Brie";  mondayMenu.cheesePlate.soft; //=> "Brie"  tuesdayMenu.cheesePlate.soft; //=> "Brie"
